title: Minor cleanups.
body:
## This PR

* always use uppercase in algorithms definition, explicit
  that algorithms are case-insensitive.

* strip off python code from spec.

title: Define an encoding for binary payload data examples
body:
## Task

How to encode binary payload data?

- base64, python repr, `<0x....>`

## notes

- base64 is a standard, though it may confuse the reader on whether he's required to 
  actually encode data

- python repr (eg. `b'\x8b\x08\x80{"hello": "world"}\x03` is more clear on showing that
  you are sending binary data.

title: Warnings in security considerations.
body:
## This PR

Further explicits that `Digest` just covers representation data. This is actually
stated all over the document, included in [Goals](https://github.com/ioggstream/draft-polli-resource-digests-http/blob/master/draft-polli-resource-digests-http.md#goals)

title: Using Digest in signatures
body:
## I expect

To better detail the usage of `Digest` in signatures, including:

- what should be included in signature for integrity (representation metadata)
- issues with signing partial representations (eg. Range-Request, PATCH, ..)
- using strong crypto algorithms

## Questions

- should we explicit here further requirements (eg timestamps, request-target, :method:, ..) 
  or that's off-topic?

## Notes

Split from #15

title: Deprecate broken-cryptographic algorithms.
body:
## This PR

Deprecate broken-cryptographic algorithms

   **NB: This RFC updates** [RFC5843] **which is still delegated for all algorithms updates**


## See

#16

title: Use http-core or 723x?
body:
## Task

Should we base on 723x or [http-core](https://github.com/httpwg/http-core) ?

title: HTTP integrity is multi-layered.
body:
## This PR

mentions signatures between Digest use-cases;

title: Remove non-cryptographic algorithms
body:
## I expect

Non-crypto algorithms be deprecated and removed from this draft.

## Because

- `UNIXsum`, `UNIXcksum` do not provide more integrity than the underlying TLS
- `MD5` and `SHA-1` are subject to collision

## Note

While crc2 and adler32 are mentioned in [http-dig-alg registry](https://www.iana.org/assignments/http-dig-alg/http-dig-alg.xhtml) I can't find any reference in RFC3230 nor in RFC5843.

@jyasskin does it sound good to you?

title: Elaborate on the use cases for a Digest
body:
https://ioggstream.github.io/draft-polli-resource-digests-http/draft-polli-resource-digests-http.html#goals says a goal is "Digest coverage for either the resource’s representation data or selected representation data communicated via HTTP.", but it's not clear to me why a client and server would use a digest. Some options include:

* To detect message corruption. This is the only reason I can think of to use the ADLER32, CRC32c, MD5, SHA, UNIXsum, or UNIXcksum algorithms, but I think it's unnecessary with modern transport protocols?
* To support signatures, for example in [Signed Exchanges](https://github.com/WICG/webpackage).
* To give the client a hint about which SRI hash will be used, to maybe help with https://github.com/w3c/preload/issues/127.

Are there others? If those are the only ones, and message corruption isn't needed anymore, we could deprecate all the non-cryptographic digest algorithms.

title: Introduction refers to TCP instead of TLS
body:
https://github.com/ioggstream/draft-polli-resource-digests-http/blame/master/draft-polli-resource-digests-http.md#L117 should probably say

> Integrity protection for HTTP content is typically achieved via **TLS** or HTTPS [RFC2818].

title: "resource" wg doesn't exist
body: https://github.com/ioggstream/draft-polli-resource-digests-http/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md refers to https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/resource/, which doesn't exist.

title: Carefully explained the checksum problem.
body:
## This PR

Explains why we need requirement for selected representation

## Note

I somewhat repeated part of the introduction to explicitly
clarify the requirement and make this document independent
from the reading of RFC3230

title: Formatting fixups
body:
NB: the majority of these changes are deletions of trailing whitespaces, which the I-D build tools dislike, but otherwise cause no change in the output format.

substanstive changes: I fixed a cross reference, modified the formatting in a couple of place, and expanded the range-request example

title: Explicitly reference content-type and content-encoding in the proposal introduction.
body:
## This PR

Explicitly reference content-type and content-encoding in the proposal introduction.

@LPardue does it sound better? Actuallly the method's too impacts on
resource representation (eg. HEAD vs GET). Should we state it here too?

title: Example for content-encoding importance
body:
```
:rfc:`7231` states that  HTTP headers and verbs alters the  payload body 
intepretation, eg.


.. gzip.compress(json.dumps(  {"a": "1"*100}  ).encode())

.. code-block:: http
   :caption: Questo è un file json compresso all'origine con gzip -
             il payload body è in base64 per leggibilità.

   POST /entries/1234 HTTP/1.1
   Content-Type: application/json
   Content-Encoding: gzip

   H4sIAItWyFwC/6tWSlSyUlAypANQqgUAREcqfG0AAAA=


.. code-block:: http
   :caption: A proxy altering the Content-Encoding, request semantic changes
             resulting - though the samei payload body -  a disordered byte-sequence

   POST /entries/1234 HTTP/1.1
   Content-Type: application/json

   H4sIAItWyFwC/6tWSlSyUlAypANQqgUAREcqfG0AAAA=

title: DISCOURAGES is not an RFC2119 keyword
body:
> This RFC DISCOURAGES the use of MD5 algorithm for security reasons.

DISCOURAGES is not a 2119 keyword and therefore has little normative affect.

Suggestion would be to replace the sentence with:

"The use of the MD5 algorithm is NOT RECOMMENDED for security reasons."

However, this just a stop gap because for "security reasons" is not qualified with discussion or citation. The final document will need to address this but I think we can live with things for the time being.

title: Refer to RFC8174
body: Address ambiguity of uppercase vs lowercase

title: "identity" is not a content coding
body:
## I expect

that "identity" is not a content coding. It is instead an alias to be used in the
`Accept-Encoding` and `Content-Coding` tokens to state "no content codings"

## Instead

this spec references the identity content coding.

title: Investigate the usage of PATCH
body:
## About PATCH

1- `PATCH` is not in http 723x
2- `PATCH` media type should be something like https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396 because 
servers SHOULD NOT assume PATCH semantics for generic
   media types that don't define them, such as "application/xml" or
   "application/json".  Doing so will cause interoperability issues,
   because the semantics of PATCH become specific to that resource,
   rather than general.
3- it's difficult to use patch + checksums, like @LPardue said

## Hypothesis

1- warn people about PATCH+Digest
2- don't forbid PATCH+Digest

title: GitHub pages is a little messed up
body:
Oops. 

Because I forked the repo, the way GitHub pages works to self-host a HTML version of the I-D is a little messed up. This repo points at mine, which is not the correct source of truth. 

I think what we need to do is add a gh-pages branch to the master repo, I can submit the PR to update it with files and update README.md to point to your HTML.

Sounds ok?

title: Make this compliant with Markdown workflow
body:
I ran MT's instructions on how to set up a repo for the Markdown workflow. This PR means that others will be able to run `make` to generate the HTML, txt and XML deliverables. See https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/master/doc/REPO.md

The markdown had a few syntactical issues that prevent the document generations tools (i.e. kramdown) from making progress. I fixed them up just enough to get over the bar. A bit more work would be required. 

Getting started with tool prerequisites: https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/master/doc/SETUP.md
